snippet: Gen. Sedky Sobhi argued that America’s presence in the Middle East and its “one sided” support of Israel had mired it in an unwinnable war with Islamist militants.
abstract: Scholars are examining significance of 2005 paper submitted to the National War College in Washington, DC, by Gen Sedky Sobhi, who is now stepping into power as a military leader in Egypt; analysts say paper, offering a strong argument against an American military presence in the Middle East, offers an early and expansive look into the thinking of a new generation of military leaders and reflects wide public opinion in the Arab world.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from London, and Kareem Fahim from Cairo. Steven Lee Myers contributed reporting from Washington, and Elisabeth Bumiller from Fort Campbell, Ky.

lead_paragraph: Gen. Sedky Sobhi argued that America’s presence in the Middle East and its “one sided” support of Israel had mired it in an unwinnable war with Islamist militants.

headline.seo: Egyptian Military Official’s Paper Criticized U.S.
headline.main: In Paper, Chief of Egypt’s Army Criticized U.S.
headline.print_headline: U.S.-Egypt Tie: Glimpse of Ire By Army Chief

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
